body: WITH the academic year now at full speed on its 19 campuses, some 200,000 City University of New York students are finding themselves threading their way around cement mixers, pile drivers, cranes and jackhammers, in some places circumventing holes in the ground where buildings will rise, in others attending lectures in temporary trailers or at odd
title: On CUNY's Campuses, The Subject Is Change

body: GOULD-Alice. 88, on August 25. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Lawrence and Eleanor and mother-in-law of Jane and Kenneth. Lifelong resident of Manhattan Beach, member of
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GOULD, ALICE

body: COHEN-Hyman. Died August 24, age 70. Survived and cherished by his wife of 50 years Mary, sons Peter and Howard, daughter Esther, grandchildren Paul and Max, daughters - in - law Gina and Deirdre, son-in-law Alan and sister Rebecca. Hyman Cohen was a veteran of the U.S. Army. He was an outstanding member of the community. He was known for his
title: Paid Notice: Deaths COHEN, HYMAN

body: Lena Cymbrowitz, a first-term state assemblywoman from Brooklyn, died yesterday in Manhattan. She was 43. Her family said she had been ill for a long time, but gave no details. Ms. Cymbrowitz, a Democrat, represented the 45th District, which includes Sheepshead Bay, Manhattan Beach, Gerritsen Beach and parts of Flatbush, Midwood and Brighton Beach.
title: Lena Cymbrowitz -- Brooklyn Assemblywoman, 43

body: EVER since they bought it in 1967, Pete and Niki Spanakos have enjoyed living in their brilliantly white all-steel house in Sea Gate, Brooklyn. The beachfront house, believed to have been designed in 1936 by William Van Alen, architect of the Chrysler Building, is known in the neighborhood as ''the sugar cube.'' Now that their children are grown,
title: Streetscapes/Sea Gate, Brooklyn; Beachfront House, Shining White and Made of Steel

body: HEYMAN-Sander. Deceased July 3, 2000. Survived by daughters Susan Bell of Manhattan Beach, CA, Nancy Ostlund of Tucson, Arizona and sister Rosalie Heyman of White Plains, NY. Born January 26, 1908 in Brooklyn, NY. Educated at City College of NY and Brooklyn Law School. Acted four years in NY theatre and movies. Wrote sketches for Broadway plays as
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HEYMAN, SANDER

body: The two blond women with the tousled Frederic Fekkai haircuts were looking at snapshots over customized Cobbs (hold the ham, hold the cucumber, hold the avocado) at Millie's Place, the salads chased by iced tea, two Equals apiece. ''Does she look good or does she look good?'' asked the first woman, a 48-year-old grandmother, who asked to remain
title: Shopping the Madison Avenue Of Manhasset (Don't Say Mall)

body: Each night, a Russian immigrant couple set out with their two young ones to stroll through the dusky streets of Manhattan Beach in southern Brooklyn. The parents, Roman and Inna Flikshtein, greet their neighbors up and down Girard Street with friendly nods and waves. Their 13-year-old daughter, Michelle, lags behind, slurping a Popsicle and
title: Family's Monkey Is Rare, And So Is Its Legal Battle

body: DENNER-Ethel. Passed away peacefully on her birthday June 20 at the age of 90. Beloved wife of the late Dr. I. Charles Denner. Loving mother of Toby, Judith & Paula. title: Paid Notice: Deaths DENNER, ETHEL

body: The Tin Man grew up to be a psychiatrist, and the Scarecrow became a musician. Dorothy works in a boutique. They were fifth graders in 1958, all ponytails and bobby socks and cardigans, when they staged ''The Wizard of Oz.'' They and 28 classmates had performed the play at Public School 100 in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, and on the evening of May 17,
title: 42 Years Later, a Troupe Finds Itself in Oz Again

body: FOR CHILDREN Theater ''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' presents a bee who rejects toiling in the hive and decides instead to fly off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Staged by the Culture Project. Maya's story is told through rod and shadow puppets. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, at Lafayette Street,
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Joseph Wolfson, an aquatic Peter Pan who was one of the first surfboarders to master complex maneuvers on the smaller ''body board'' in the 1970's, died in a car crash on a Los Angeles freeway last Monday. He was 50. Wolfson became a legend known as Dr. 360 for his ability to spin completely around while riding a big wave. He won national and
title: Joseph Wolfson, Surf Legend, Dies at 50

body: FOR nonresidents, Manhattan Beach is a destination. They come either for Kingsborough Community College, at the eastern tip of the peninsula, or for the 40-acre beach park. For residents, though, it is a bedroom community of mostly spacious homes, many with waterfront views. ''Manhattan Beach is almost completely surrounded by water, so it's sort
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn; Peninsular Suburb, and Destination

body: In retrospect, it seems only natural that Paul Matus should found a Web site about the New York City transit system. He grew up in Flatbush, not far from the Church Avenue trolley, the last trolley in Brooklyn, which stopped running in 1956, when Mr. Matus was 10 years old. ''Whenever I got a good report card I would get a trolley ride,'' said Mr.
title: NEW YORK ON LINE; All About Transit, Not Only for Buffs
